Award.AwardTitle: Sustaining the Engagement of Highly Diverse Communities of High School Students in an Out-of-School Engineering Residency Program: An Exploratory, Capacity-Building Study

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This one-year project studies the experiences of eight high school-aged youth in an after-school engineering program at the New York Hall of Science, a science center in the highly diverse neighborhood of Corona, Queens. During the 2016-2017 school year, these young people will work with visiting Designers in Residence to learn more about engineering design, and to design, develop and implement new hands-on engineering design activities and programs for museum visitors. The goal of this research is to identify the specific activities and ways of working together that invite participants to draw on their diverse backgrounds to contribute to their shared work, and that encourage participants to engage with the perspectives and ways of thinking, working, teaching and learning that are distinctive to the engineering professions. Evaluations of many engineering programs targeting under-represented youth have shown that such programs can have a meaningful impact on outcomes and educational trajectories. But there is little research that investigates in any detail what particular programmatic structures, policies or practices contribute to creating an environment in which youth from diverse backgrounds choose to persist in and pursue their engagement with engineering and cultivation of an identity as an engineer.

This study will use participatory action research to capture the perspectives and experiences of the program participants, and draws on literature on the state of K-12 engineering education, and on the experiences of underrepresented youth in undergraduate engineering programs, to inform its design and focus. The difficulties encountered by non-dominant youth in engineering education are broadly acknowledged, but cannot be addressed effectively until program designers and educators have better insight into how these youth negotiate the process of building strong, meaningful connections between their own interests and identity and their potential induction into a new identity as a student of engineering. The results of the study will inform programmatic decisions and further research at NYSCI, in the museum-based education community, and among educators and researchers seeking to support underrepresented high school students who wish to explore engineering design and prepare themselves for success in undergraduate education programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering education research urgently requires a deeper understanding of how youth from non-white, immigrant backgrounds—particularly girls and young women—experience programmatic efforts to engage them in the practices of learning and teaching others about engineering. The difficulties encountered by such youth are broadly acknowledged, but program designers and educators continue to struggle to understand how to address these challenges in ways that are meaningful to their target audience. This work requires deeper insight into how youth negotiate the process of building strong connections between their own cultural identity and their potential induction into a new identity as a student of engineering.

To both address this broader need and determine how informal learning experiences specifically can serve as engineering pathways for these young people, researchers from the New York Hall of Science (NYSCI) worked with a diverse group of New York City public high-school and early-college students on a participatory action research project. These “Design Lab Fellows” were recruited from a larger pool of participants in NYSCI’s Science Career Ladder (SCL) program, all of whom work as docents on the museum floor (called “Explainers”) while also attending a wide variety of professional development and training opportunities.

Through the project, researchers were able to: engage a group of eight Fellows in a 10-month participatory action research project, leveraging their unique skills and perspectives as participants in the SCL; shift NYSCI’s broader perspective on the intersection of cultural diversity and engineering and its relevance to how we engage visitors with engineering; deepen NYSCI’s understanding of how to ensure the SCL is inviting and valuing diverse perspectives among our participant youth; and aim to make NYSCI's expertise in this area visible and relevant to the engineering education community through conference presentations and journal articles.

Significant results include the fact that many Fellows, when prompted at the project’s start to describe what an engineer looked like to them, represented an engineer as a non-gendered entity, looking rather at characteristics an engineer would need. This demonstrated how open the Fellows were to thinking about who an engineer is and how they might or might not relate to being an engineer themselves. And as the Fellows progressed through the project, it became clear to researchers that these young people did not need to be given identities. Rather, they needed opportunities to connect the dots of their own experiences in the SCL to see that they were already building skills that are, in fact, engineering skills.

Other significant results include the changes Design Fellows helped identify via their research to make the different activities in NYSCI’s Design Lab space more culturally responsive—and thereby more effective as an informal learning opportunity—for the museum’s very diverse visitors. In total, Design Fellows observed, gave feedback, and prototyped changes to set up and/or facilitation to each of the eleven Design Lab activities, including “Chain Reaction” (during which visitors use many different modified everyday objects to build together a Rube Goldberg machine) and “Help Grandma” (during which visitors brainstorm and build solutions to help “Grandma” [dolls] with everyday challenges she might encounter).

For the “Costumes” activity, during which visitors are asked to design a costume for themselves or for large mannequins using fabric and other knowable materials, Fellows explored ways to integrate more culturally relevant examples to expand the kinds of costumes visitors were making. One of the first things they did was use pictures of clothing from different cultures—an Indian sari, a Japanese kimono, among others—and projected them around the space. As they worked to create a more culturally inclusive environment, the Fellows identified the activity’s name as a thing they would like to change. Their reasoning was, if NYSCI wanted visitors to incorporate their culture into their designs, they might not make that connection if the activity was called “Costumes” as they would not necessarily define their cultural garb as such. As a result, we changed the activity’s name to “Fashion Design,” and the Fellows did indeed begin to see that the kinds of things visitors were making diversified. These kinds of changes in the ways activities engage and support engagement in engineering identity are also relevant to science center field as a whole. Findings like these and others will also be shared at local and national science center and museum conferences.
